DRaQbCdw9IISqNR8zQz6yQ.text: We decided to try this place for dinner based on reviews here. On the waiters suggestion, my husband and I each decided to try one of the specials. RYiAZ5a-d2GaaO15H_-kCg.text: So you need a car or transportation.  This is in a shopping area called The District neighboring the Green Valley Ranch hotel, about 12 miles from the Tropicana end of strip.  If you're in the area, give it a try.  The shops were empty.  The only thing busy on a Tuesday night was this restaurant.  On this night it was a bit too busy.  It seems a company decided to have dinner for at least 50 employees who took up a good portion of the place, which is fine, except it made it impossible to talk.  The acoustics were not good.  So loud.  Seems like this wasn't a good mix of regular diners and a company party.  I would have suggested they book the whole place for the evening.  The bread to start was yummy.  The house cabernet delicious, nice and dry.  The margarita pizza was good.  Pasta is house made and delicious.  Sauces good.  Family run.  Decent portion of food.  But a couple of issues that really shouldn't happen here.  The waiter seemed very rushed and that we had arrived before the company employees were seated.  Waiter did his best to check on us but he was always flying by the table.  I felt like if I asked a question it would interrupt him.  He must have had too much to do to serve his customers more attentively.  In part because he was in a hurry he took my order incorrectly.  I usually order chicken picatta, one of my favorite dishes and I've eaten it in many restaurants.  When it arrived it was chewy and looked light brown instead of white. Definitely not the tender chicken that comes with picatta.  But I was hungry and it took quite awhile to get the food so I didn't question it, just figured I'd ordered a dish that wasn't good.  A bit of a disappointment.  When the bill came I noticed it said veal picatta, not chicken picatta.  As it turns out he took down the wrong order.  Normally I would have said something about it tasting bland and not tender but again, he was in a big hurry and I was hungry.  This kind of ruined the rest of the meal because I don't like veal picatta, haven't ordered in years and normally don't eat meat.  I wish I would have had an opportunity to taste the chicken picatta.  When I pointed out the discrepancy on the bill he apologized and took the dinner off the check, which was very nice.  But my stomach felt a bit queasy the rest of the evening.  Honestly all the times I've ordered chicken picatta I've never had a waiter bring me the wrong thing.  They need to slow down a bit here and listen more closely.  I think the dishes are probably pretty good here.  And the owner is right on site.  He was really busy too or I would have said something.  Just don't order the veal.  I'd stick to pasta and happy hour...

mD4pYyM00BiBOBQo6DYvSQ.text: Overall a good experience.  The server grew on us but initially he seemed a little put out by doing his job. When we arrived, we were seated on the patio.  I like the patio, BUT the misting fans were distracting because they were not maintained, so they leaked large drops of water instead of mist, and that then would get blown onto us and our table.  So, we asked to have the misting part shut off, so we were not getting sprayed with water.  The issue here is that apparently, they are so broken that even when they shut the misting off, the fan in front of us had a stream of water spraying our still(For our entire meal), so they HAD to shut the fan off too or we would just have been sprayed the whole meal.   Then it became a little too warm to sit on the patio.  We didn't complain about it, we just tried to enjoy our meal, knowing at this point the misting was not fixable.     Meal wise, we had a number of items, my mom had the chicken parm sandwich and said it was good, my older kids each had pasta al vodka and i tried this and it was good.   My younger kids split the margarita pizza and it was ok.  Crust was good.    My wife and I split two items, the Porchetta sandwich and a pizza with Prosciutto and greens.  I had them bring me Balsamic Glaze for the pizza and WITH that, it was good.  Without it, it was just bland and missing something.   The Porchetta sandwich was lacking IMO.  I am a huge Porchetta fan and this was just not Porchetta in my opinion.  It lacked all the seasoning and flavor of a good porchetta, and they put a roasted pepper on it, which I felt was just masking the lack of flavor in the porchetta with an overly strong peppers flavor.  So, I won't order that again.  I saw a number of things on the menu that I wanted to try, so I will probably try here again, but what I had didn't live up to expectations.  Last observation...LOVE the idea of tables on the patio with padded seating, BUT...the table prevented you from being able to put your legs under the table, so you just can't sit close enough to the table to the point where it is uncomfortable to sit there.  I wanted to be able to lounge back in the "couch" but then slide up to sit at the table and eat and i pretty much had to sit back the whole time and even take my food off the table to sit and eat.

egsmIReYba_bp07lVnxCAg.text: Had a horrible experience here Friday night. Took a date for dinner and we sat on the patio to try and enjoy the music. The table next to us had a big group of people that were all standing and visiting and the blatantly in our personal space. I tried not to focus on that in anticipation of a delicious meal. My date ordered the Tagliatelle Bolognese and I ordered the featured Steak. Our server either awkwardly approached the table or avoided us altogether because his path was being blocked by the big group that was standing and visiting around us.  When the food finally arrived it was delivered by a food runner not our server. Usually it is common practice for the server to check on and see how the first couple of bites taste. The mashed potatoes that were part of my steak were ice cold. After about 5 minutes of still no server I flagged someone else down and asked them to send over our server. I told him the potatoes were cold and he said he would "take care of it". I could see the kitchen from our table and he handed the plate back to one of the cooks.  Now I have worked in kitchens before and anytime a plate is returned you do your best to make sure it is perfect the second time around. After a minute or two I saw my plate sitting on the counter and the server was standing back near a drink station. No one from the kitchen flagged him down and he was not alert and staying on top of the situation eventually the plate came back and again the potatoes were cold. I was not happy. By this time my date only had a few bites left so I wasn't about to send it back twice. The server never stayed and asked me to check the potatoes and no manager or anyone else came by to apologize or ask us how everything went. When the check came there was nothing taken off of the bill or any offering of a free dessert. The way I see it there were many opportunities to salvage my experience and get my business back. A3yGmpEzsQwxqUG6rgw0RA.text: I do like this place.  My first experience was great!!  Second experience, not so great.  First time we had a lovely waiter who was super attentive. RzjxJiH7NUGvMqSSvNiSSw.text: Never in my life have I been treated this poorly in a restaurant much less "fine dining". I went there Saturday night with my boyfriend for date night. We brought our own bottle of wine ($20 corkage fee which is a great price) and sat outside on the patio. I ordered the special of the day which was a seafood medley with risotto and my date ordered the gnocchi bolognese. We decided we'd split both entrees in which we asked for extra plates. Once the meals got to our table we started with the risotto, finished our first meal and then proceeded to the gnocchi.   To start, the risotto was fantastic. It was flavorful, the seafood was well prepared and very delicious. However, the first bite into the gnocchi tasted off. The sauce simply didn't taste good and the meat had a strange unappetizing flavor to it. I told our server promptly. When he asked us what was wrong, I told him. I felt like he didn't believe me and we were making up excuses to return the plate. So upon feeling like he was searching for more of a reason, I was perfectly honest and said it tasted like Chef Boyardee (which it did). Granted, maybe I shouldn't have said that, but he asked me. He immediately got offended and with a snarky smile told me he would tell the chef what I said.   He takes our plates and everything else off our table aggressively, slamming dish-ware onto his tray and did not make any eye contact. At this point I feel extremely uncomfortable. So I ask him if I offended him by telling him we didn't like the food. He says "I just told the chef who I have been friends with for over 10 years what you said and he wasn't happy about that". I immediately told him, "why you didn't have to do that?" He did not ask us if we wanted anything else. Did not apologize. But insisted on being rude and making us feel like we did something wrong by not liking the dish.   We were prepared to order deserts or possibly another entree but felt incredible awkward. You're telling customers the chef is pissed at you? You're going to disengage and treat them like they're wrong because of that?  We left feeling disappointed and upset. This service should never be tolerated. Listen here, Donacilano (our server). Not everyone is going to like their entree. It is OK.  You work in a customer service industry (just like myself) that means that you SERVE us, your guests.   Upon arriving we told each other this would be a great regular date spot, but not anymore.

SwhLHZ8NF0EvaDG-_36Uhg.text: I've been coming here regularly for the last year so a review is long overdue. Let's start with the fact that this is located in the district in a primo location that offers happy hour specials and great food.  The service is prompt and usually on point with casual Italian accents drifting through the restaurant bustle. Definitely make reservations for the weekend nights.  My fave is the  Tagliatelle Bolognese - house made al dente pasta with a hearty, yet light meat sauce.   My wife likes the Linguini & Clams - house pasta with a light and savory brothy sauce that coats every noodle and a generous amount of fresh clams.  We've also tried the  Zuca Ravioli -  it can be a hit or miss. When it's good, the browned butter sage sauce is as delicate as the butternut squash ravioli. When it's bad, the sauce looks watered down and sage is undercooked leaving an unpleasant taste.  Burrata - whether in the salad or anti pasta, it looks and tastes house-made fresh.  Penna Cotta - perfect consistency, not too firm. The accompanying wine poached pears are a unique treat.  Tiramisu - Perfect and can convert any non-tiramisu lovers.  It's one of our favorite spots that I hope will be around for a long time.   Bon appetite!

For the chicken fettuccine alfredo, the chicken was completely unseasoned, dry, and incredibly hard to chew and swallow. The atmosphere of the restaurant was uncomfortable, it was a very small area filled with many people and so much noise you could hardly hear the person next to you. SbEfecY5HCIef-fqY7vgzQ.text: I've seen and passed by Bella Vita so many times whenever I'd go to the District but never tried them until very recently.  What caught my eye was the "Best of Vegas" stickers so instead of going to Pizza Rock at the Green Valley Ranch, we decided to see if those stickers hold water.  The place was packed for a Thursday night.  All the seats at the bar area/counter were occupied.  There was a singer that night yet the crowd's noise easily overshadowed and won over his voice/singing.  Yes, the place was unusually loud/noisy.    We were seated right away and served with the complimentary bread and olive oil/balsamic vinegar.  Our server was quick to offer their specials for the evening but we opted for fettuccini alfredo, penne a la vodka, ceasar salad and pizza.    The complimentary bread was good so I asked for seconds.  The ceasar salad was a bit too creamy for my liking.  Didn't get the garlicky undertone and the subtlety and added umami of mashed anchovies.  The pizza was very good.  The crust was neither thick nor thin and had a good bite to it.  The pizza sauce gave a good balance to the slight bitterness of arugula, the saltiness of the prosciutto ham and the creaminess of the parmesan shavings.  The pasta dishes were pretty standard though. ..nothing to rave about.  I didn't finish my penne (I guess due to me overstuffing myself with pizza and the complimentary bread).  And oh...they were not skimpy with cheese :).    Food was decent and reasonably priced.  Staff was quick and very responsive. I personally just found the ambience a bit loud, stuffy and crowded.   If you're in or around The District, you may want to support a local joint and give them a try.

Slow service, bland food, and a chaotic atmosphere make for a restaurant best left to others.  I came here on a Saturday evening. The place was packed, a generally good sign. We were promptly seated, and waited....and waited....and waited. Our server finally showed up and read off a laundry list of specials. Translation: the chef has a lot of food items he needs to get rid of quickly before they spoil.  Our food was served in a reasonable timeframe. While the food itself tastes good, it's nothing memorable nor special. There's nothing that makes the food worthy of the $25-$30 per plate. Save yourself $10 a plate and head over to Olive Garden.  Now, onto the ambience, or rather, the lack thereof. Bella Vita tries very hard to pack as many customers as possible inside. That together with the turnt housewives throwing napkins between tables and live music creates an atmosphere closer to what I'd expect in a 711 in North Las Vegas, not an Italian restaurant in Henderson.  With all the amazing restaurants in Las Vegas, there just is no reason to try Bella Vita. Olive Garden and Applebee's, please STOP HAVING CHILDREN.

It's situated mostly down the side of the restaurant so it's protected from most traffic noise. The restaurant has had live music on a few of my visits that created a lovely ambiance. The Antipasto Misto was delicious with a great variety of meats, cheeses, and other cheese plate goodies. I enjoyed my Chicken Puttanesca and my husband enjoyed his Veal Parmesan.   On my most recent visit I came in for Happy Hour and absolutely loved it. It was a beautiful day so the patio was the perfect place to relax with good food. The Happy Hour Menu offers an impressive selection of dishes that can definitely be put together for a full meal. The drink side of the menu offers half a dozen different wines, some cocktails, and several beers. The $5 Peroni was shockingly generous.   From the Happy Hour Menu here's what we enjoyed. Our favorites were the Gnocchi al Pesto (perfectly cooked), Caprese Salad (that balsamic glaze!), and Meat Balls (well seasoned with plenty of delicious red sauce to dip bread into). The Penne Alla Vodka was missing something in the flavor profile, but I couldn't put my finger on specifically why it lacked flavor. The Shrimp Scampi had perfectly prepared shrimp with a decent sauce, but with only three shrimp it wasn't worth $7 like the rest of the dishes. Not on the Happy Hour menu, but an excellent choice was the Spumoni for dessert. The gelatos, chocolate shell, and sauces were so good!

He seemed put-off by our group for whatever reason, so that was a bummer. However, the assistants were very gracious about our needs (extra salad dressing, water/soda refills, etc...)  Food- the arugula/apple/blue cheese salad on the special menu was delicious. Arugula with crisped slab bacon, apples, blue cheese, hearts of palm and a sweet/tangy dressing, it hit all the notes. The house bread was also good and delivered with EVOO/Balsamic to dip. I tried both the gnocchi and the tagliatelle in the bolognese, and would order either again. The gnocchi were pillowy; the tagliatelle noodles were my favorite, though. Can't pass up a homemade pasta noodle!  I did have to send my Cioppino soup back. This dish is a scrap, as it was. The "broth" was more of a thicker tomato sauce and the bowl had hot spots, as though reheated. The fish was rubbery, off-tasting and tough to get through, also, as if nuked. They assured us that wasn't the case, and took the plate back but seemed perturbed and argued over my observation. I apologized profusely, as I typically don't send my dishes back. As a diner, I felt the server could have handled it a lot more graciously, as it was embarrassing.  Finally, I left my phone at the table, and realized just down the street, turned around and sure enough they host stand had it ready-in-waiting. I really appreciated that. They explained it to be 20% off the second most expensive entree ordered. Also a nice touch. An excellent addition to Green Valley Village Walk. We will definitely be back again.
